plist.p: Well, good morning, everyone, and thank you for coming along today. After a few presentations, two from me and two from Laurie, so a little longer than would normally be the case, we'll open up the Q&A which Steve Webb is going to chair. And in a minute, Laurie will take you through the main features of last year's numbers. But most of today's content will focus on our plans for the UK and on how we're tackling the other priorities for Tesco, those that were laid out a year ago at this very meeting.

Since my first preliminary results announcement, I think we've acted where the strategy wasn't delivering as we'd have hoped. In the U.S., we got Fresh & Easy moving towards breakeven before accelerating investments. In Japan, we announced our decision to exit after eight years. At the bank, we slowed down migration to focus on greater reliability in the future. And also in the UK, took a significant step to correct our pricing position; and then in January, acted decisively to address the underperformance at home.

I've been here a year now, and the thing about coming back to the UK has been it gave me a unique opportunity. Eight years is a long time in business, and that time away meant that upon my return I could take a rather dispassionate view of the business here; at the industry, look at it from just about every angle. That led to a fundamental reappraisal of the UK. And whilst it's not original to me, I have to say that I believe in the UK this industry has been running up the down escalator.

Space growth is too fast. More very big stores aren't the answer any longer. Customers are moving faster to smaller stores and to the Internet. Social media will soon be as influential as press advertising. And when Tesco does its best work, it does so by following the customer so that's what we're going to do. We're going to change our approach. And that will mean there'll be slower space growth. There'll be fewer, bigger, new stores. There'll be more convenience. There'll be more online. And crucially, there'll be more personalization. And there'll be more localization. Quite simply, we're going to build a better Tesco; a more modern Tesco for customers, for our colleagues, for the communities that we serve and, therefore, for our shareholders.

The Tesco of the future will put more back in for customers. We'll get back to driving profits through sales. We'll make multi-channel a profitable reality. We'll act decisively where we see underperformance and we'll strike a better balance between growth and returns for shareholders.
Over to Laurie now to take you through last year's numbers. Thank you.

Thank you, Phil; so good morning, everyone. I'm going to start my presentation this morning with the group headlines followed by a brief commentary on segmental performance. I'll then cover the balance sheet and cash flow position including an update on the financial metrics that I set out a year ago.

Group sales for the year were £72 billion, up 7.4%. Group trading profit was £3.8 billion, up 1.3%; and underlying profit grew by 1.6%. Group profit before tax increased by 5.3%. Underlying diluted earnings per share increased to 37.41 p. And consistent with our policy of growing dividends broadly in line with underlying diluted EPS on a constant tax rate basis, the full-year dividend is 14.76 p per share, up 2.1%. We've held net debt stable in the year and we're pleased to report an increase in our return on capital employed, up 40 basis points to 13.3%.

These results are in line with the revised market expectations post-January and do demonstrate the breadth of the Tesco Group. Thanks to strong performances internationally, particularly in Asia, we've been able to deliver profit growth for the group despite a challenging year for the UK and the impact of PPI for the bank.

In the UK, we saw strong total sales growth driven by good new store performance. But our like-for-like growth was disappointing, particularly in the second half. This wasn't helped by reduced inflation from big price drop and a weak Christmas affected by substantial increase in competitor couponing activity. That said, for like-for-like, our like-for-like recovered somewhat post-Christmas.
Net trading margins also reduced in the second half, and I'll return to this, and particularly the shape from half two 2011-2012 into half one this year and of course latter through to half two.

In Asia, we delivered a good performance across all markets, with solid like-for-like growth for the year. The reduction in like-for-like sales growth through the fourth quarter does reflect reduced inflation in China and Korea and the earlier timing of the Lunar New Year Festival in 2012.

Our performance in Thailand was obviously affected by the floods, falling from 8% like-for-like in the first half to 2% like-for-like in the second half. I'm delighted to say the country is getting back to normal and with Tesco Lotus returning to strong growth.

Margins in Asia are up by over 60 basis points in the year. This is mainly due to the swift resolution of our insurance claim in Thailand, which has mitigated the profit impact of store closures. Korea and Malaysia both had a good year for sales and margin growth, although this was offset by increased losses in China. In common with other businesses, we faced a challenging year there.

A resilient overall performance in Europe was impacted by two factors. The crisis tax in Hungary which had a material effect on profits was £38 million in the year. And despite a strong performance in sales, profits in Poland were held back by significant disruption connected to the opening of our new distribution center and non-food stock write-off near the end of the year.

Excluding the impact of Hungary crisis tax, we saw decent double-digit profit growth in Central Europe and a pleasing performance in light of the broader economic issues affecting the Eurozone. Our Irish business delivered a robust performance in the context of a severe recession there.

The particular circumstances of both Ireland and Hungary have led us to focus on driving trade from existing stores, and we've scaled back our investment in new space. Focusing our efforts on stores we've got has driven a strengthening like-for-like and a continued increase in market share in both markets.

Moving on to the United States, Fresh & Easy has delivered another strong top-line performance and we've reduced losses by nearly 18% year-on-year. This is the first full-year reduction in losses since entry.

An increasing number of stores are now reaching shop-door profitability, and more will reach that point over the coming months. This chart on EBITDA, which is a good proxy for positive cash flow, shows it. The red dotted line in the middle represents the point where stores have crossed into positive EBITDA. In addition to the 30 stores on the right of the line that are already making positive cash, the two bars to the left of the line represent 118 stores and shows that a large number of stores are very close to crossing the line. Nearly half these stores are within $5,000 per week of being in positive territory, so that's a much more encouraging picture.

Tesco Bank increased its baseline profitability, that is, profit before all key provisioning, very strongly. It's up by 29% to £203 million. Fair value releases reduced significantly from £155 million to £22 million in the year, and going forward these will be immaterial.

Trading profit for the bank was £168 million which is after the £57 million charge of PPI that we announced at the half year. And net provision for PPI stands at £75 million which puts us in an appropriate position based on our claims experience to date. A decision to slow down the final stages of migration resulted in a hit to profit of around £40 million, which will now begin to reverse.

The bank's overall capital position improved again with the risk/asset ratio improving by 240 basis points to 16%. The liquidity of the bank has also improved, the retail bonds issue giving us greater diversity and helping the bank's funding position.

As announced at the half year, we have treated Japan as discontinued. This results in a total charge for the year of £142 million below the after-tax line which includes a small trading loss of £25 million, which is similar to last year. I'm pleased to say that the divestment process is nearing completion, and we'll update you as and when appropriate.

Turning now to the balance sheet, net debt remains stable for the year at £6.8 billion. This is a little behind our guidance we gave at the half year, and that's due to firstly, the impact of Christmas, our trading results on cash flow and a lower working capital inflow linked to the higher stock levels than we planned.

Group capital expenditure was slightly below the half year guidance at £3.8 billion due to tight control of spending. And operating cash flow from retail operations is down slightly year on year to £3.8 billion. Again, this is wholly due to the working capital inflow.

Our strategy to release value from the property portfolios had another successful year, generating £376 million of property profits from about £1 billion worth of disposals. The launch of our first property fund in Asia completed successfully after the year-end, raising £379 million from 17 mature malls in Thailand. We saw exceptionally strong demand with the fund pricing at the top end of the range and being 11 times over-subscribed. Since launch, it's been trading 10% ahead of its listing price, a strong indication of overall value of our operations in Thailand and, of course, elsewhere in Asia.

Finally on the balance sheet, our IAS19 pension deficit has increased to £1.4 billion, largely as a consequence of the reduced corporate bond yields and generally lower market returns. We announced changes to the terms of our defined benefit scheme last month in order to make it more sustainable over the long term. We've also made a one-off cash contribution of £180 million to the scheme after the year-end. This is in anticipation of the forthcoming outcome of the triennial actuarial valuation which we believe gives a more accurate indication of the likely costs of future funding of the scheme.

One year ago, I set out four key financial metrics which I said I would update you on at these meetings. Starting with the top left of the slide, we improved our return on capital employed from 12.9% to 13.3%. This improvement benefits, obviously, from Japan now being classified as discontinued.

We held fixed charge cover and net indebtedness broadly flat. Both measures will, of course, be directly affected by the UK investment plan we've announced in 2012-2013. As you'll remember, our target for fixed charge cover is between 4 and 4.5 times with a ratio of 2.5 times to lease-adjusted net debt to EBITDA.
Finally, I've already mentioned that we came in slightly under the guidance on capital expenditure of 5.3% of sales and that's right in the middle of the 5% to 5.5% range I laid out last year.
I'll now hand over to Phil to give you an update on the year and our plans for the UK business. Thank you.
Thanks, Laurie. I'm going to begin with a candid assessment of the business as I see it and then focus on our plans for reinvigorating the UK.

It's been a tough year. Although the international businesses performed strongly, delivering an 18% rise in profits, that just compensated for the reduction in the UK, leaving overall group profits only slightly up. That means that despite some really good things going on in Tesco last year, it wasn't one we could really be proud of.

You know the background. In a difficult environment for consumers at home, we've chosen to face into the need to improving the shopping trip for our customers and tackle with increasing urgency some long-standing issues. Those decisions have clearly had important financial consequences for the year we're reporting today, for the year ahead and, of course, for our shareholders.

Deciding to give up some short-term profit to safeguard the long-term health of the business was a very difficult call but I strongly believe it was necessary. Having looked at the business hard since last summer and, in particular, in the light of a disappointing Christmas, I felt the pace of change needed to accelerate to get Tesco UK back where we want to see it: leading, performing and growing again.

I said a year ago that I had inherited a great business built around customers and staff with high quality assets around the world and multiple opportunities for growth. I still strongly believe that. But what's clearer to me now than it was then is exactly how much we can do with the right plan in the UK. The recession hit Tesco hard and it was longer and it was deeper than we'd anticipated. We did well to maintain our growth through most of it but with results, too heavy a load was placed on the UK to support the group.

We have to confront this uncomfortable truth and that's really the background to the decisive action that we have taken in the last few months. There was a need for change. Many of you saw it and now we're driving it. And we're also, as you've seen, renewing the management team in key areas to deliver it.

It has three aspects. First, we had to start putting more back into the business than we were taking, and I'll come back to the UK in a minute. Second, we couldn't just wait for economic recovery. We had to reduce the drag and risk to our growth by taking action on other areas of the business that were holding back our performance such as the U.S., Japan and the bank. I think we can point to tangible evidence of progress in each of these areas.

And third, and at the same time, we had to increase our focus on the long-term strategic objective at ensuring the business remains well-positioned for the opportunities and for the challenges of the Internet. This is important because we recognize that issues facing retailers today are not just cyclical, they're structural. We've already put more resources behind this and the pace of change has noticeably quickened in both food and in non-food. And that means it is right to take a different approach to allocating capital, a new approach that fits the future. Again, I'll come back to that shortly.

These actions are why the priorities I set out for my team last April are every bit is relevant now as they were then. As a reminder, they're shown on this slide. These are our immediate management objectives, the things we're very focused on. I'll touch on each of these in my presentation starting with international, but I'll spend the majority of my time on the UK.

Internationally, we had a good year. That 18% profit growth I mentioned would have been 22% without the impact of the Hungary crisis tax. I'm pleased with that performance because in several of our large markets like Ireland and Hungary, economic conditions remained very challenging.

There are many good things to talk about with the international businesses. U.S. losses started to fall and I have more confidence now that we'll look back and say, "This was more than a turning point for losses. It was a turning point for Fresh & Easy." Of course, there's a lot more to do and I'm quite sure some will say it would have been better if the reduction in losses had been greater.

While sales growth remained strong in the second half, the reductions in costs that we'd achieved in the first half didn't continue at the same rate in the second. But I don't think anyone can argue this isn't a decisive change of trend after four years of rising deficits.

The simple truth of it is that we're all proud of Fresh & Easy and what it delivers for customers today. The stores look good. They're getting better all the time so it's not an accident that the two-year like-for-like is running at over 20%. Of course, we also want to be proud of what it delivers for our shareholders.

We did plan to get to 300 stores. That's what we need to cover our overheads. But because I want to see more existing stores cross over into profitability before we push on, I think it's right to be more measured on new capital for the time being. This means we should be at or around breakeven by the end of 2012-2013 before overheads but after distribution and campus costs. And when we get close to that, when we prove that, we'll pick up the pace of new space.

Another strong feature of the international performance was market share growth. You can see from this table how we've performed this year in our markets in Asia and in Europe. These numbers are representing the main good progress, continuing the improvement which we've sustained for more than a couple of years now.

Our business in Thailand has had an extraordinary year by any standards. The flooding catastrophe which engulfed the country didn't do lasting damage to Tesco Lotus. Instead, it came out stronger. At the worst, about over 150 of our stores, mostly express, closed and all four depots underwater. I don't know how you feel about it but I love this picture. I've never seen anything like it in my years in the business. Despite challenges like this, we kept our like-for-likes and our profits growing although the latter was helped thankfully by having adequate insurance cover.

I was also pleased with the further growth in success of our multi-format strategy. This chart shows how diverse our international space has now become. 20% of our space today is in compacts, in supermarkets and in convenience stores. The new growth, though, is increasingly in these smaller formats, 49% in this year's program as you can see from the chart. This is true across international with the exception of Turkey and China where hypers are still less developed.

And despite what appears to a widespread misconception, we're not calling time on the hypermarket. The success of the extra program internationally demonstrates there's a lot more to come from these stores. The cumulative improvement in sales in the 31 conversions in Europe and the three in Asia that we've completed so far is 17%. The future of the hyper may well be smaller; it may be food and service-focused with a tight general merchandise assortment and a strong clothing offer. But in that slimmed down form, I believe there's plenty of life and growth in it yet.

There were two markets in international where performance wasn't so good. First, and as Laurie has explained, we had a distribution center issue in Poland in the second half. It put a dent in Europe second half performance after an excellent first half as you all have seen. It's behind us now.

Second, things got tougher in China. We're not immune from the slowing economy, from the impact of high inflation and even higher wage costs. You can see it in industry like-for-likes, and that's led us to take a more cautious stance on the market, at least for now. We've decided to hold back on an increased hyper development program for the time being. We'll open only 16 stores this year instead of stepping up as we had planned. We still believe that China can be an engine of growth, but it's constrained by the short-term challenges. It's a similar approach that I have taken in the U.S.A.: slow down, rebuild, then accelerate.

Finally on international, whilst Homeplus had another great year, the changing regulatory environment in Korea towards large retailers looks like being unhelpful. We haven't yet seen how the new restrictions on trading hours; they limit 24-hour trading and require large retailers to reduce the number of trading days by between one and two a month. We don't know how they'll be implemented across the country, but our current view is it will have the effect of reducing like-for-likes modestly in the year ahead.

Closing on international, that we could weather these challenges and still achieve an 18% growth in trading profit to £1.1 billion is really pleasing. That's more profit than any of our domestic peers and a reflection of the quality of the business we've created in less than two decades.

Before I turn to UK Retail, a few words on the bank. Tesco Bank is a major part of our strategy but I completely understand why people have been frustrated with the timelines. However, I'm pleased to say that the three-and-a-half-year project is almost complete. And because we've taken great care to get it right, we now have a great platform, a low-cost model, robust modern systems, good market positions; and with 75% of the business already conducted online, enormous potential for the future of financial services at Tesco.

The next large new product will appear soon after migration, starting with mortgages. As we put more than three years of tradition behind us, the bank is well-placed to deliver good growth starting this year.

I'm going to move on now to the main topic of today, to the UK. I spoke earlier about the background to the decision that we have taken. You know how it's been. Take a look at these charts which illustrate some of the causes. The first shows, during a period of recession and prolonged strain on consumers, how we continued to drive profit growth ahead of sales until 2011-2012 margins, that's the light blue line, were gently rising. This was despite slowing like-for-like sales, that's the red line, and the burden of incremental costs. We didn't miss a beat, but that meant we put a strain on the business.

A consequence of this was that, as this next chart shows, the productivity loss of the stores was too great. This chart looks at our productivity index. We use the term PI, an expression of the hours stores are allocated relative to the very precisely measured tasks they have to do. I've said we've been running the stores too hot and this index, running well over 100 for a sustained period, is what I mean by that.

The effect in the stores is that some colleagues are working too hard. Staff are being pulled around their departments too much and don't have time to look after their areas. And above all, our standards are not as consistent as we'd like. We simply haven't been giving our staff what they need to look after customers as well as they want.

It was not that we were all that we are delivering a bad shopping trip for millions of customers every week. That's not it. At the core of it is that the key elements of the shopping trip, the things which influence where customers shop and how much they spend stopped improving in the small, the incremental ways they've done for a decade.

The truth is in retailing, every little helps. Those small improvements are often subtle. They're as much about reliability and consistency from one trip to the next as they are about new and different things. But actually, they're the lifeblood of like-for-like growth in the industry.

There were other components, of course. Non-food was more of a problem for us than for others, especially as we'd had our big surge in new space for non-food much earlier in the last decade. At the heart of it though, I believe, is we were simply taking more out than we were putting in and that's not sustainable. It wasn't that the business is blind to these issues either, but we expected the tide of economic recovery to lift us and, frankly, it didn't arrive.

The shopping trip isn't broken and I think this important next chart illustrates why. Even when were at the top of our game in 2002, we never were seen to be the best of everything in respect of these key aspects of the shopping trip. Winning in the industry is having the right blend of performance on these measures and as I said before, getting back to making steady incremental improvements by putting more in for customers.
I think you can see the influence of staffing here. It's all too clear and that's why it's our first priority. If they're working too hard, they're just not as helpful.

And that's behind what we did in January. We know what's wrong and importantly, we know how to fix it. Whereas we thought we should fix it over three years and had developed a plan to do so, it came to me in January, it was vital to face it, to deal with it now and get on with it. Addressing the staffing issue is the biggest single component and this is where we've decided to do three years' work in one. And what we've found in the trial stores is that customer perception of all aspects of the shopping trip gets better if we sort out the hours, if we train our people. The billion pound investment plan to build a better Tesco is under way.

So on to the plan to build a better Tesco. It's got six elements. Firstly, helping our people deliver great service; secondly, making our stores better places to shop and to work in; thirdly, delivering great value for money; fourthly, building the right ranges of quality products; fifthly, making sure that we get back to having the right conversation with our customers; and finally, making clicks and bricks a potent combination for customers. We're making a significant investment in each of these areas and it's the coming together of them that will build a better Tesco for our customers. I'll just take each of them in turn quickly now.

First, staff and service, putting the staffing levels back in and training the staff in key departments, particularly in the fresh areas and in the bigger stores. We're recruiting, we're training, and we're equipping 8,000 staff right now, and many of them are already in the stores. This activity alone will require revenue cost investments of over £200 million. It'll bring PI back to the index of 100 in the key areas. This is the three years' work in one that some of you have heard me talk about.

All of the Extra staff are dedicated to particular departments. In the first wave, that's produce, that's meat. It's chilled convenience. It's beers, it's wines and it's spirits. In the 200 pilot stores where we've made these changes already, we're seeing encouraging results against control stores. And you can see them on this slide.

It's very encouraging. First, our mystery shopping scores have improved. Second, while sales in the newly invested departments improved the overall store sales increased, too. In the initial 16-store trial which began last summer, like-for-like has improved by 1.2%. And in the more recent 200-store extension, after 17 weeks, like-for-likes are 1.1 points better so far. These results are very clear. The same changes are now being extended to all Extras and all Superstores and it'll be live in just four weeks' time.

The second element is stores and formats. There's a lot to talk about here, but in essence of it – the essence of it is we're going to love the stores we've got and the overall pace of new developments will moderate. The pace of refreshing stores has already stepped up and we're aiming to complete all the large stores by the end of 2013. We'll do 430 stores this year to improve the look and the feel, using warmer colors and materials, better lighting, improved site lines across the store and, as you see here, less functional signage.

It doesn't involve high levels of capital for store because the stores generally are well invested. But it does make them look less clinical, less industrial. As you can see here, there's again an emphasis on key departments like counters, like fresh foods and bakeries. 40% of club cardholders will notice the difference this year alone.

Some of you know I like to get into the detail and having examined every aspect of what we have in terms of space and what's right for the future, we're taking a fundamentally different approach. Putting down a lot of new space has produced great results for Tesco in the past, but I don't think the current race for space across the industry is the key to a sustainable future. So on development, there will be less new space overall; 1.5 million square feet this year, nearly 40% less net new space than last year. Our new space will also reflect the growing importance of our online business in general merchandise and our desire to focus on the most productive use of new capital.

Sure, we'll expand in all formats but we'll prioritize expanding Express at least as fast as we are now. It already looks after a third of our customers. We'll invest more, as I've said, in dotcom-only stores. We'll build out space where we're committed to complete. And on hypers, we'll still be doing them, but as I've said earlier, they'll be smaller; food, services and clothing-focused. And that makes sense given the rapid growth we're seeing in non-food online.

And just before the epitaph of the hyper is written, let me say in the UK we have just 10 stores over 100,000 square feet and only 52 stores over 80,000 square feet. The vast majority of our 750 or so large stores remain very profitable, very popular stores.

Take a trip to Slough or Kingston Park or Sandhurst or (33:46) if you need a reminder. Strategically, this is much more about how we anticipate the influence of the Internet in the future than it is about dealing with a surplus of space today. It's much more about saying what we want the Tesco to be in the UK in 2020 than saying where it is now is wrong.

Price and value is the third, being best all-around value for money. We made big changes to our price list with a big price drop last September. It got off to a good start but it wasn't sustained because we lost the marketing battle at Christmas. We're now more competitive; that's an important step on the journey, but there's more to do to get the blend right on price, promotions, on couponing and on loyalty.

We didn't get that blend right over Christmas but we've been doing a better job since then. As it's a very commercially sensitive area, I'm sure you'll understand if I don't give you chapter and verse on our plans. But our customers are going to see more change and they're going to see it soon.

Fourth, range and quality. We're picking up the pace on ranging, starting with a complete re-launch of all of the Tesco brands. Again, it's not broken but it does need a refresh. Better quality, better packaging, more innovation. This will touch over 8,000 products and 40% of our sales in the next 24 months. We've already started the work beginning with Tesco Value.

Even before we re-launch it, it's growing at over 10% because more customers use it to make tight budgets go that bit further. And as you can see from the new packaging, every day value is a big improvement. Over 200 products have been reformatted using higher quality ingredients. They've all have been benchmarked and passed against their equivalent.

We're also starting to use the capability we've already deployed with success in Express to make our ranging more store and more format-specific. I think there's a big opportunity here. Of course, Tesco will always have broad appeal. But having the same range in Alfreton and Amersham isn't doing all we can for the different needs of customers in those stores. So that's changing, too. There'll be more personalization. There'll be more localization.

This is where dunnhumby is playing a very important role. We've brought them right back where they belong, to the heart of the business. They help us by taking insight from Clubcard to make the customer experience at Tesco more personal, more relevant. And this is a very substantial project for the UK in the years ahead.

Fifth, brand and marketing. We've already made changes in marketing. I'm pleased to say that Tim Mason is heavily involved in the work. Only last week, we began our creative agency review, the first in well over a decade. Quite simply, we need a different conversation.

Finally, part six; making clicks and bricks a compelling combination for customers is how I see Tesco remaining one of the long-term winners. It's a key part of the building a better Tesco plan because of that. Sure, we have to fix some things in the UK business right now, but we'll also keep a clear focus on the strategic opportunity of the Internet for a business with our scale, with our reach, and with our capabilities.

By 2020, every person under the age of 21 on the planet will have been born in the digital age. It's already changing the way people live their lives and the way that they shop. Right now, I, you, could order a non-food item on your smartphone from Tesco Direct and have it delivered tomorrow by 3:00 in the afternoon to a local express store for no charge. I believe we are very well-placed to prosper in the digital age.

Food was first. We're making money. We have a model no one can match in our international markets. I'd rather be coming at this from a strong base in food than from anywhere else. The challenge for everyone, of course, is making money in non-food online.

In total, our online businesses grew sales last year to over £2.8 billion and increased their profits despite a strong development cost headwind. And in the UK, the online businesses are doing very well.

It's not bad, really, if you think, a 47% market share at Tesco and still growing. Tesco Direct is also going through a big step change in our offer right now. Starting with grocery, sales grew 13% and profits increased. Extra investments in the business adding capacity, delivery slots, more flexibility on delivery charges, including a monthly fee for multiple orders, were well-received where we offered them to customers. They also really like food Click & Collect. It's now in 45 stores and adding to our growth rates.

With the opening of Enfield dotcom-only store, we've almost completed our London network, enabling much more range to be offered across the very diverse London market and giving many of our large, high-density stores a bit more room to grow.

The last two London-focused dotcom-only stores will open before the end of 2013 and this model will then be applied more widely, with stores penciled in for Oxfordshire and the West Midlands after London is complete. Obviously, this isn't all about the UK either; developing the operating model once and applying it everywhere is a great example of our applying group skill and group scale.

Internationally, in Ireland and Korea, the operations are doing well. In Korea, the business is already the size of more than two of our largest hypermarkets and it doubled its profitability in the second half, helped by the developments of the inventive mobile apps and the now-famous virtual stores in subways. We made a strong start in Prague with sales ahead of plan and the starts not far off in Warsaw. I don't have to tell you, that's a different approach to capital productivity.

In non-food, Tesco Direct began launching its new online platform that will bring much more content for customers; a new website with much more functionality, a doubling of the range plan this year from 40,000 at the beginning of the year, 80,000 now, to 200,000 by Christmas, thanks to Marketplace where third-party vendors can sell through tesco.com. That began the first stage of its phased launch just three weeks ago.

Click & Collect in non-food is now in approaching 800 stores. It takes 70% of our non-food online volume. The 70 Expresses we put in it are doing very well and because this is one key area where we're developing a competitive edge, we'll have 700 Expresses offering this by the year-end. 700.

Few people are more than 10 minutes from a Tesco in the UK. That ubiquity, that convenience for millions of customers should be a big advantage for Tesco. There's a lot to do here, but we're already very profitable online. We have a uniquely strong global supply chain and an unrivaled store network that can give us compelling advantage in fulfillment for customers. That's why we're pushing on fast with our Clicks & Bricks strategy.

So that's the essence of building a better Tesco plan. Clearly, we expect each element of it to contribute to the improvement in like-for-like sales. We'll do a lot in year one, but some elements will take a bit longer.

I've got the team I want to drive through this plan. Here they are. Many of you know them from our international investor trips to Europe and Asia.
